page.lettertext:
fol.245r
May it please yo
r
good L. The 10 of this moneth being com
[e]
as farre as
Swolle
, in going towardes the Campe, and there
attending
e arrivall of
e
Councel of Estate
, I receaved thos
[e]
letters and schedules, w
ch
her
M
tie
and my
LL.
and yo
r
L. sent
unto me, bearing date
e 1 and 2 of this present. When
e Councell was come thither, w
ch
was the next day after,
having commoned first w
th
S
r
Francis Vere, I procured an as-
semblie not onely of
e Councel, but of
e Deputies of
e Provinc
[es]
and I offered them to open her M
ties
letters to
e
states
in
caus
[e]
case they founde themselves thereto to be sufficiently autori
zed. Which I did for good respect, for
at it had bin a
question in their dealinges before, whether they in that
place, or those at the Hage, having both like commission from
e generalitie of
e Countrey, were to exercise
e power of
e
generall States. But in this matter of her M
tie
they
disclamed
at autoritie, and putt me over to
e Hage for deliverie
of my letters. Howbeit I omitted not to signifie
e effect of
those letters, and in all
at I was able to amplifie
e reasons,
and to pray them not to hinder
e execution of my charge.
For her Hig
nes
promise was so past,
at it could not be revoked,
and I had order thereafter, to cause
e troupes
at were desired,
to put them selves in present readines. They were muche
amazed at the matter, and used great intreatie,
at no separation
might be made of
e Englishe from
e rest, till
e Campe were
come to
Coevoerden:
upon hope
at
e Enemie, upon
e viewe
of their nombers, would come to present composition. But
conferring upon it w
t
S
r
Francis Vere, and
ceaving plainely
by discourse,
at it was but a motion to gaine a litel time; for
at
e Enemie is hardie and
e place well provided: and finding
therew
t
all
at their marching first to Coevoerden, and then
afterwardes to
Flushing,
might both weaken them in strength,
and putte them farre out of order, when her Hig
nes
would be
served, I
sisted
p
cisely upon
e pointes of my charge; and
requested them earnestly, to graunt a patent to every c
o
pany
to repaire to his garrison, and
at there they might remaine,
fol.245v
untill such time as they were sent for. This I urged
c
o
tinually, as having no kinde of libertie, to dispose in other
sorte of her M
ties
desseigne: w
ch
was also so confirmed by
S
r
Francis unto them: who cotinueth there in place, and
hath resolved not to alter, but to prosecut
e matter, as I
have begonne it. In
e meane time, because they did
refuse to determine there upon it, referring me hither to
this assemblie of
e States I departed from thence
e next
day following, and came hither to
e Hage w
t
all possible
speede. I left
e Campe at
at time w
t
in a mile of Swolle
from whence I thinke they will not sturre, till they heare
w
at
is said by
e States of this place. Yesterday
morning I presented my letters in their publike meeting
w
ch
when I had heard, being openly read (for I had no copy)
sent unto me) I noted a certaine clause, w
ch
I am very
muche afraide will put me to some trouble. For it goeth
w
t
condition,
at if
e armie of
e States may be commodiously
dissolved, and
e forces of her M
tie
w
ch
have served in
e armie
c
o
veniently returned, that then
e
French King
shall have
e use of those succours
at are promised unto him. But, as
if I had not understoode it, I urged very earnestly the
Kinges necessitie and
e importance of
e matter in respec[t]
of these countreis, and proposed all
e pointes of
e instru[ctions]
sent unto me, w
t
out leaving to their choise, to denie he[r Majestie]
her demaunde. They said but little as then to any p[arte]
of my speeche; but, as their custome is c
o
monely in causes of [con-]
sequence, they required some time to signify their answear[.]
They had notice of
e mater before my comming to
e Hag[e]
and had receaved out of
England
a copie of
e Contract be[tween]
her Hig
nes
and
e King: w
ch
I
ceave by some frindes, they doe [highlie]
dislike to have bin done w
t
out their privitie, in regard of
at [Contract]
w
ch
is made w
t
them already. But if they seeme in
at respect [to]
complaine in publike place, I have mater enough for a[nsweare]
I am onely nowe to seeke, w
ch
way I shall be able, to rec[oncile the]
forsaid clause, w
t
at w
ch
I proposed. For, as I learne under[hand from]
fol.246r
a frinde among
e States, they doe minde to take holde of those
wordes of
e letter, and will seeme to take no knowledge,
at her
M
tie
meant otherewise, but to make her suite conditional. I
will excuse it as I may upon
e Writers oversight, and keepe
e
course that is begonne in
p
paring
e Companies, and in declaring
plainely to them,
at both
e Contract w
t
the King, and her M
ties
letter to my self, doth apparantly signifie
at there must be no
denial. Nevertheles if they chance to be so willfull, as to
stand in contestation, and to oppose against me, as they may,
it will be greatly behoofull,
at I be strengthned from her Hig
nes
w
t
some plainer knowledge of her meaning. And because it is
a mater of so great a consideration, I thought w
t
all speede
to advertise yow of it, and humbly to beseeche yow, to write
about it w
t
the soonest. I have certaine intelligence
from
e Campe, at this very instant,
at S
r
Francis Vere hath
obtened patents for his troupes, to be placed in townes adjoining
to Swoll, and
at
e rest of
e campe is marched towardes Coevoerd
e
I am also told assuredly,
at
e answear of
e states is ready to
be sent, and is framed upon
e advantage of
e point afore-
m
e
tioned.
Count Philip
w
t
his troupes
at have served
in
France
, is expected every houre: and as soone as they re-
turne,
M
r
Buzenval
hath in charge, to request
e loane of
so much mony, as may suffice for certaine monethes, to
intertene 2000 men, to be levied in suche sorte, as
e King shall
appointe. And for mine owne part I beleeve, he shall
speede of his purpose. For if they in this c
o
trey, shall be
forced to surcease from an offensive warre, as me thinkes
there is apparance, when
e Englishe are departed, there will
be so muche remaining of this sommers contribution, as the
King may be pleasured, and an overplus reserved.
And thus I take my humble leave. From the Hage. July 15
1592.
fol.247r
1592 16 July To my L. Trea
s
When the bearer was ready to depart w
t
my letter,
e Sta[tes]
sent unto me a transcript of their answear: w
ch
I caused ou[t]
of hand to be copied againe, and I send it heere unto yo
r
L.
For it may chaunce to come before
e originall letter, w
ch
they
will send some other way. I see their aunswear is no
other, then expected at their handes, taking hold fast of
at clause of her M
ies
letter. I should mervel not a
little, that they call me not againe, to some further
c
o
munication, but that they knowe well enough,
at I will
prosecut that course,
at I have hitherto proposed, and endevou[r]
w
at
I can, to put
e c
o
panies in a readines. Their answear
is also general for
e motion of
Britaine:
but no doubte in
particular, they will come to
at w
ch
was their offer.
And for
e day of their l
re
, though they dated it for
yesterday, it was signed but to day: w
ch
is
e custome of
their College, to put
e date of
e day, when they take
their resolutions, and not of
e time when their l
re
s are
signed. July 16 1592.
fol.247v
A postscript to my L. T
re
r 16 July 1592
